comments: The course discusses theory, research, and application in the persuasive effects of communication in social and mass contexts. Primary focus of the class covers the effects of messages on attitudes, opinions, values, and behaviors. Applications include political, commercial, and public service advertising; propaganda; and communication campaigns.   Students found the course material “interesting” and “useful.” Many said that it “had potential,” but was overshadowed by the general disorganization of the class.   Reviews of Professor Simons were in some cases negative. Several students claimed that he was “not a very engaging lecturer,” “never stuck to the syllabus,” and was constantly revising due dates.  This course does not fulfill any general requirements. There are no prerequistis listed for this course. It is open to both freshmen and upperclassmen.
